title: 115_hr6200
content: The Act is titled the "Transportation Workforce Modernization Act" and includes a Transportation Worker Retraining Grant Program. The Secretary of Transportation may make grants to institutions of higher education, consortiums, or trade associations to establish a transportation worker retraining program for workers affected by job loss due to automated driving systems. Grant recipients are responsible for developing a curriculum for the program aimed at training and preparing workers for new jobs. The program aims to provide grants for retraining workers affected by job loss from automated driving systems. Recipients can use funds for studies, pilot programs, and testing new job roles. Selection criteria include research resources, curriculum development capability, and expertise in solving transportation problems. The program provides grants for retraining workers affected by job loss from automated driving systems. Recipients must demonstrate commitment to carrying out workforce development programs. The Federal share of the grant is a dollar for dollar match of costs. The Secretary must submit a report to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure detailing the review process and specific evaluation criteria used. The program includes specific evaluation criteria, descriptions of the review process, and explanations for recipient selection. A tracking mechanism will be implemented to determine the sectors of industry displaced transportation workers come from, skills participants are retrained for, program usage, and demographic information. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of $25,000,000 in appropriations for fiscal years 2020-2022 to carry out a program for transportation worker retraining. Recipients may receive one-time grants determined by the Secretary of Transportation, with funds available for 3 years after authorization. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of driverless vehicle adoption on the workforce, trucking industry, wages, job loss, and creation of new jobs.
